title: Number of moles for same heat

content.question: Substance <math alttext="delta H of vaporization, in kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Î”</mi><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>(</mo><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 20 40 The table above provides the values for some physical properties of <math alttext="H 2 S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Approximately, how many moles of <math alttext="H 2 S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> must be condensed to release as much heat as would be released when 1 mole of <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is condensed?

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
